storyTitle: As Biometric System Administrator, I want to configure biometric device connections to achieve reliable data capture

testCases.title: Validate adding biometric device with valid parameters
preconditions: User is logged in as an administrator with device configuration permissions
Device configuration database is accessible
Network connectivity is available
Test biometric device is powered on and reachable on the network

steps.action: Navigate to device configuration page from the main menu or dashboard
steps.expectedResult: Configuration form is displayed with fields for IP address, port, device name, and communication protocol. All input fields are empty and enabled

steps.action: Enter valid IP address (e.g., 192.168.1.100) in the IP address field
steps.expectedResult: IP address is accepted and displayed in the correct format without any validation errors

steps.action: Enter valid port number (e.g., 4370) in the port field
steps.expectedResult: Port number is accepted and displayed correctly without any validation errors

steps.action: Enter device name (e.g., Main Entrance Device) in the device name field
steps.expectedResult: Device name is accepted and displayed in the field

steps.action: Select communication protocol from dropdown (e.g., TCP/IP)
steps.expectedResult: Protocol is selected and displayed in the dropdown field

steps.action: Click the Submit or Save Configuration button
steps.expectedResult: System displays a loading indicator and initiates connectivity test. Configuration is saved to the database

steps.action: Wait for connectivity test to complete
steps.expectedResult: System displays success message indicating device configuration saved successfully. Device status shows as 'Connected' or 'Online'. Connectivity test completes within 3 seconds

steps.action: Verify the newly added device appears in the device list
steps.expectedResult: Device is listed with correct IP address, port, name, and status showing as active/connected

postconditions: Biometric device configuration is saved in the database
Device status is set to active/connected
Configuration change is logged with administrator username and timestamp
Device is ready to capture biometric data

testCases.title: Reject invalid IP address during device configuration
preconditions: User is logged in as an administrator with device configuration permissions
Device configuration page is accessible
Form validation rules are active

steps.action: Navigate to device configuration page from the main menu or dashboard
steps.expectedResult: Configuration form is displayed with all required input fields visible and enabled

steps.action: Enter invalid IP address format in the IP address field (e.g., 999.999.999.999)
steps.expectedResult: Inline validation error message is displayed below or next to the IP address field indicating 'Invalid IP address format' or similar descriptive error

steps.action: Enter valid port number (e.g., 4370) in the port field
steps.expectedResult: Port number is accepted without errors

steps.action: Attempt to click the Submit or Save Configuration button
steps.expectedResult: Submission is blocked. Submit button is either disabled or clicking it displays an error message. Error message clearly states 'Please correct the IP address format before submitting' or similar

steps.action: Clear the IP address field and enter another invalid format (e.g., 192.168.1)
steps.expectedResult: Inline validation error message is displayed indicating incomplete or invalid IP address format

steps.action: Attempt to submit the configuration again
steps.expectedResult: Submission is blocked with error message displayed. Configuration is not saved to the database

steps.action: Enter alphabetic characters in IP address field (e.g., abc.def.ghi.jkl)
steps.expectedResult: Inline validation error message is displayed indicating invalid characters in IP address field

postconditions: No device configuration is saved in the database
User remains on the device configuration page with error messages visible
No connectivity test is initiated
No configuration change is logged

testCases.title: Restrict device configuration access to authorized users
preconditions: Two user accounts are available: one with non-administrator role and one with administrator role
Role-based access control is configured and active
Device configuration page requires administrator privileges

steps.action: Login to the system using non-administrator user credentials (e.g., regular employee or attendance viewer role)
steps.expectedResult: User is successfully logged in and redirected to the appropriate dashboard for their role

steps.action: Attempt to navigate to device configuration page by clicking menu item or entering URL directly
steps.expectedResult: Access is denied. System displays 'Access Denied' or '403 Forbidden' message. User is either redirected to their dashboard or shown an error page stating insufficient permissions

steps.action: Verify that device configuration menu item is not visible or is disabled in the navigation menu
steps.expectedResult: Device configuration option is either hidden from the menu or displayed as disabled/grayed out for non-administrator users

steps.action: Logout from the non-administrator account
steps.expectedResult: User is successfully logged out and redirected to the login page

steps.action: Login to the system using administrator user credentials
steps.expectedResult: Administrator is successfully logged in and redirected to the administrator dashboard

steps.action: Navigate to device configuration page from the menu
steps.expectedResult: Access is granted. Device configuration page loads successfully with all configuration options visible and enabled

steps.action: Verify that all device configuration features are accessible (add, edit, delete, test connectivity)
steps.expectedResult: All configuration features are visible and functional. Administrator can interact with all form fields and action buttons

postconditions: Non-administrator user access attempt is logged in security audit log
Administrator has full access to device configuration functionality
Role-based access control is enforced correctly

storyTitle: As Attendance Manager, I want to review biometric attendance logs to ensure data accuracy

testCases.title: Filter attendance logs by date and employee
preconditions: User is logged in as an Attendance Manager with log viewing permissions
Attendance logs database contains test data with multiple employees and date ranges
At least 50 attendance records exist spanning multiple dates and employees
Export functionality is enabled and configured

steps.action: Navigate to attendance logs page from the main menu or dashboard
steps.expectedResult: Attendance logs page is displayed showing a list of attendance records with columns for timestamp, employee ID, employee name, device information, and status. Filter panel is visible with date range and employee ID filter options

steps.action: Select start date in the date range filter (e.g., 2024-01-01)
steps.expectedResult: Start date is selected and displayed in the date picker field

steps.action: Select end date in the date range filter (e.g., 2024-01-31)
steps.expectedResult: End date is selected and displayed in the date picker field

steps.action: Enter specific employee ID in the employee ID filter field (e.g., EMP12345)
steps.expectedResult: Employee ID is entered and displayed in the filter field

steps.action: Click Apply Filters or Search button
steps.expectedResult: System displays loading indicator and then shows filtered logs. Only attendance records matching the specified date range and employee ID are displayed. Record count is updated to reflect filtered results

steps.action: Verify that all displayed records match the filter criteria by checking dates and employee IDs
steps.expectedResult: All displayed records have timestamps within the selected date range (2024-01-01 to 2024-01-31) and employee ID matches EMP12345. No records outside the criteria are shown

steps.action: Click the Export or Download CSV button
steps.expectedResult: System initiates CSV file download. Browser displays download progress or save dialog

steps.action: Open the downloaded CSV file in a spreadsheet application
steps.expectedResult: CSV file opens successfully and contains all filtered records with correct data including timestamp, employee ID, employee name, device information, and status. Data matches what was displayed on screen. File includes appropriate headers

steps.action: Verify the number of records in CSV matches the filtered results count
steps.expectedResult: Record count in CSV file matches the count displayed on the attendance logs page

postconditions: Filtered attendance logs remain displayed on screen
CSV file is successfully downloaded to user's device
Filter criteria remain applied for subsequent operations
User action is logged in system audit trail

testCases.title: Search attendance logs by employee name
preconditions: User is logged in as an Attendance Manager with log viewing permissions
Attendance logs database contains records with various employee names
At least some attendance records have rejected or error status
Search functionality is enabled and configured

steps.action: Navigate to attendance logs page from the main menu or dashboard
steps.expectedResult: Attendance logs page is displayed with all attendance records visible. Search box is prominently displayed at the top of the page or in the filter panel

steps.action: Locate the search box for employee name or ID
steps.expectedResult: Search box is clearly labeled (e.g., 'Search by Employee Name or ID') and is enabled for input

steps.action: Enter a specific employee name in the search box (e.g., 'John Smith')
steps.expectedResult: Employee name is entered and displayed in the search box. System may show auto-suggestions if available

steps.action: Press Enter or click the Search button
steps.expectedResult: System displays loading indicator briefly and then shows filtered results. Only attendance logs matching the employee name 'John Smith' are displayed. Record count is updated

steps.action: Verify that all displayed records belong to the searched employee
steps.expectedResult: All displayed records show employee name as 'John Smith' or matching variations. Employee ID is consistent across all records

steps.action: Scan through the displayed logs to identify any rejected or error entries
steps.expectedResult: Rejected or error entries are visually distinct from normal entries. They are highlighted with different background color (e.g., red or yellow), different text color, or special icon/badge indicating error status

steps.action: Click on or hover over a rejected entry to view details
steps.expectedResult: Rejected entry displays additional information such as rejection reason, error code, or tooltip explaining why the entry was rejected

steps.action: Verify the visual distinction is consistent across all rejected entries in the results
steps.expectedResult: All rejected or error entries have the same consistent visual highlighting. Normal/successful entries do not have this highlighting. The distinction is clear and easily identifiable

steps.action: Clear the search box and verify results reset
steps.expectedResult: When search box is cleared, all attendance logs are displayed again without the employee name filter applied

postconditions: Search results remain displayed until user clears search or applies new filters
Rejected entries remain visually highlighted
Search query is logged in system audit trail
User can perform additional actions on the filtered results

storyTitle: As Biometric System Administrator, I want to handle biometric device disconnections to maintain continuous attendance tracking

testCases.title: Detect and retry biometric device disconnection
preconditions: User is logged in as Biometric System Administrator
At least one biometric device is connected and operational
Device status monitoring service is active and running
Alert notification system is configured and operational
System clock is synchronized for accurate timing measurements

steps.action: Navigate to the biometric device management interface and verify the target device shows 'Connected' status
steps.expectedResult: Device status displays as 'Connected' with green indicator and last heartbeat timestamp is current

steps.action: Simulate device disconnection by unplugging the network cable or disabling the device connection
steps.expectedResult: Device physically disconnects from the network

steps.action: Monitor the system response and note the time taken to detect the disconnection
steps.expectedResult: System detects the disconnection within 10 seconds and updates device status to 'Disconnected' with red indicator

steps.action: Observe the system behavior for automatic retry attempts over the next 2 minutes
steps.expectedResult: System automatically attempts to reconnect to the device every 30 seconds (at 30s, 60s, 90s, 120s intervals)

steps.action: Check the device connection logs to verify retry attempts are being recorded
steps.expectedResult: Connection logs show timestamped entries for each retry attempt with status 'Connection Failed' or 'Retry Attempted'

steps.action: Continue monitoring the disconnected device for 5 minutes without reconnecting
steps.expectedResult: System continues retry attempts every 30 seconds throughout the 5-minute period

steps.action: After exactly 5 minutes of disconnection, check administrator notification channels (email, SMS, in-app notifications)
steps.expectedResult: Administrator receives alert notification indicating prolonged disconnection with device details, disconnection duration, and timestamp

steps.action: Verify the alert contains device name, location, disconnection time, and recommended actions
steps.expectedResult: Alert message includes all required information: device identifier, location, exact disconnection timestamp, duration (5 minutes), and troubleshooting suggestions

steps.action: Reconnect the device by restoring network connection
steps.expectedResult: Device reconnects successfully on the next retry attempt (within 30 seconds)

steps.action: Verify the device status updates to 'Connected' and reconnection event is logged
steps.expectedResult: Device status changes to 'Connected' with green indicator, and system logs show reconnection event with timestamp

postconditions: Device is reconnected and operational
All disconnection and reconnection events are logged in the system
Administrator has received and acknowledged the alert notification
Device status dashboard reflects current connected state
System resumes normal monitoring of the device

testCases.title: View real-time device status on dashboard
preconditions: User is logged in as Biometric System Administrator
Multiple biometric devices are registered in the system
At least one device is currently connected
Device status monitoring service is running
Dashboard has real-time update capability enabled
Browser supports real-time updates (WebSocket or polling enabled)

steps.action: From the main menu, click on 'Device Management' or 'Device Status Dashboard' option
steps.expectedResult: System navigates to the device status dashboard page

steps.action: Observe the dashboard layout and verify all registered devices are displayed
steps.expectedResult: Dashboard displays a list or grid view of all registered biometric devices with their current status

steps.action: Check each device entry for status indicators including connection status, device name, location, and last activity timestamp
steps.expectedResult: Each device shows: device name, location, connection status (Connected/Disconnected with color coding), last heartbeat time, and device health indicators

steps.action: Identify a currently connected device and note its status as 'Connected' with green indicator
steps.expectedResult: Target device displays 'Connected' status with green indicator and recent last activity timestamp

steps.action: Simulate device disconnection by physically disconnecting the target device or disabling its network connection
steps.expectedResult: Device is physically disconnected from the network

steps.action: Keep the dashboard open and monitor for automatic status updates without refreshing the page
steps.expectedResult: Within 10 seconds, the dashboard automatically updates the device status to 'Disconnected' with red indicator without manual page refresh

steps.action: Verify the disconnection timestamp is displayed and updates in real-time
steps.expectedResult: Dashboard shows 'Last seen: [timestamp]' and displays duration of disconnection that updates in real-time

steps.action: Reconnect the device by restoring its network connection
steps.expectedResult: Device reconnects to the network successfully

steps.action: Observe the dashboard for automatic status update to reflect reconnection
steps.expectedResult: Within 30 seconds (next retry cycle), dashboard automatically updates device status to 'Connected' with green indicator without manual page refresh

steps.action: Verify the reconnection timestamp and current heartbeat status are displayed accurately
steps.expectedResult: Dashboard shows updated 'Last seen' timestamp reflecting current time and connection status shows 'Connected' with active heartbeat indicator

steps.action: Check if dashboard provides additional information such as connection uptime, total disconnection events, and device health metrics
steps.expectedResult: Dashboard displays comprehensive device information including uptime percentage, disconnection count, and overall device health status

postconditions: Device status dashboard accurately reflects current state of all devices
Real-time updates are functioning correctly
Device is reconnected and showing connected status
All status changes are reflected in the dashboard without manual refresh
Administrator has visibility into current device health and connectivity
